properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A total of 20 to 25 centimetres of snow is expected beginning overnight tonight through Thursday evening. Strong winds will accompany this snow and will generate locally blowing snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

Area: Schefferville

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

Snow will begin to taper off Wednesday morning. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A strengthening low pressure system will track northward out of the Dakotas today, giving heavy wet snow to areas near the Saskatchewan Manitoba border. The snow will begin early this morning in the south and work its way northward throughout the day. Current indications are that 10 to 20 cm will fall with this system, although local amounts could be higher. Some surrounding regions may also be added as the system moves in, depending on the track of the system. As you go east, amounts will be less as the precipitation will be lighter and transition to rain. Localized areas of freezing rain are also possible, however the main impact of this system will be snow. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-02T01:28:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-01T09:29:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1454778635.2020

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Between 25 and 45 millimetres of rain are expected between Wednesday morning and Thursday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Strong northeasterly winds gusting to 80 km/h and falling snow will produce blizzard conditions in Arviat and Rankin Inlet beginning early this morning. Blizzard conditions will gradually diminish overnight Wednesday into early Thursday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-02T00:32:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-01T08:33:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3839844812.2020
Area: Arviat, Rankin Region including Whale Cove
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Les Suêtes Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Les Suete winds gusting to 100 km/h will develop overnight and persist on Thursday. Winds are expected to diminish Thursday evening. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-01T23:40:41-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall amounts to come... The Schefferville region should see a period of heavy snow. Snow will begin gradually Wednesday evening and intensify over the following night. Snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 centimetres are likely by Thursday evening. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult locally. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

Area: Schefferville
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A strong southerly flow will strengthen winds to 70 gusting 90 km/h near midnight tonight before diminishing somewhat Wednesday morning. Winds will remain gusty throughout the day Wednesday. The strong winds will also produce reduced visibilities at times in blowing snow. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-01T19:26:14-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A strengthening low pressure system will track northward out of the Dakotas today, giving heavy snow to areas near the Saskatchewan Manitoba border. The snow will move into The Pas and Flin Flon this afternoon and amounts of 10 to 15 cm of snow are forecast with this system. Snowfall will gradually diminish Thursday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A strong low pressure system is forecast to track northward out of the Dakotas on Thursday. The track of this low is uncertain at this time, however it does have the potential to spread heavy snow over portions of southern and central Manitoba. Current indications are that snow will spread into southern Manitoba Thursday morning, working its way north throughout the day. It should end Thursday night in the south and on Friday in central Manitoba. A mixture of rain and snow could also occur in more eastern locales, again depending on the track of the system and how long the mild airmass remains in place. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-02T01:29:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-01T09:30:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2421445534.2020
Area: Lake Winnipegosis, Lake Winnipeg - north basin, Lake Winnipeg - south basin, Lake Manitoba
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A strengthening low pressure system will track northward out of the Dakotas today, giving heavy snow to areas near the Saskatchewan Manitoba border. The snow will begin early this morning in the south and work its way northward throughout the day. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm will fall with this system, although local amounts could be higher. The warned regions and amounts may change as the system moves in, so please monitor the latest forecasts and warnings. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Locations: Nain and vicinity. Time span: beginning this morning and continuing into Thursday. Remarks: Light snow will intensify this afternoon, persisting until Thursday evening. Moderate northeasterly winds will this morning and combine with fresh fallen snow to reduce visibility in blowing snow, especially tonight and Thursday. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-04-02T00:02:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-01T08:03:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0592864595.2020
Area: Nain and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow changing to rain Wednesday. Snowfall total: 5 to 10 cm. Rainfall total: 20 to 40 mm. Location: northeastern New Brunswick. Remarks: Periods of snow tonight will change to rain on Wednesday as temperatures rise above zero. An extended period of rain is then expected to last until Thursday night, when temperatures should fall below zero again. At this time, precipitation should change to flurries and taper off by Friday morning. Temperatures will remain above freezing through the overnight hours on Wednesday. The rain and mild temperatures could lead to significant melting of the snow pack and runoff. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-01T16:35:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-01T00:36:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2913453083.2020
Area: Bathurst and Chaleur Region, Miramichi and area, Acadian Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall with blowing snow is expected. Total snowfall: 25 to 35 cm. Locations: Hopedale to Makkovik. Time span: today through to Thursday evening. Remarks: Significant snowfall and strong winds up to 70 km/h will combine to reduce visibility in blowing snow today and Thursday. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-04-02T00:00:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-01T08:01:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1963992675.2020
Area: Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Prolonged Wreckhouse winds expected today and Thursday. Strongest gusts: southeasterly near 110 km/h Time span: beginning this morning until Thursday afternoon. Remarks: Strong wind gusts are forecast to continue into Thursday afternoon. At that time winds are expected to become more east-northeast which is less favourable to enhanced Wreckhouse winds. ### Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-04-01T23:46:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-01T07:47:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3278254662.2020
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
